Based on the report’s “Water Resource Management” section and the broader findings, the following points summarize recommended future work:

1. Monitor Water Levels and Manage Pumping:
   • Prioritize more intensive water‐level monitoring in areas already showing declines, particularly northwest of Llano Quemado and east of the golf course.  
   • Expand aquifer‐scale monitoring throughout southern Taos Valley, especially near high‐pumping zones.  
   • Recognize that fault‐bounded compartments can experience excessive drawdowns, so additional data collection and modeling of compartmentalized flow would help refine pumping strategies.

2. Avoid Mixing Deep and Shallow Waters:
   • Investigate the potential geochemical consequences of mixing thermal (deep) water with cooler, shallow aquifer water.  
   • Study mineral precipitation (especially zinc and other metal carbonates) to understand how mixing zones might harm water quality or clog wells.

3. Improve Well‐Siting and Water‐Quality Planning:
   • Use water‐quality maps (and other study results) to guide the placement of new public supply wells in regions less prone to thermal fluid intrusion or heavy metal mobilization.

1) Broader Geophysical Characterization.  
   • Expand the transient electromagnetic (TEM) surveys or add other geophysical methods (e.g., seismic or gravity) across a wider area to better delineate the lateral and vertical extent of basalt flows, sand and gravel layers, and other aquifer units.

2) Enhanced Groundwater Monitoring.  
   • Install additional observation wells at key locations (both shallow and deeper completions) to track water-level trends through time—particularly in areas where water levels changed significantly between the 1950s, 1980s, and 2010s.  
   • Conduct more frequent water-level measurements and link them to changing climate patterns, irrigation practices, and streamflow variations to capture both seasonal and long-term trends.

3) Expanded Geochemical and Isotopic Analyses.  
   • Collect regular samples in critical parts of the aquifer to see how major ions, trace metals, and isotopes vary over multiple seasons and water-use conditions.  
   • Incorporate additional isotope tracers (e.g., noble gases) to further assess recharge timing, groundwater mixing, and any potential hydrothermal contributions.  
   • Compare ongoing irrigation and precipitation sources to refine the understanding of irrigation return flow.

4) Improved Recharge and Water-Budget Estimates.  
   • Perform dedicated infiltration studies to confirm the infiltration rates for recharge from streams, irrigation fields, and precipitation.  
   • Refine chloride mass-balance methods with more localized precipitation sampling and chloride deposition measurements to reduce uncertainty in recharge estimates.  
   • Re-assess stream–aquifer interactions with year-round streamflow measurements, especially where seasonal flow volumes can be substantial.

5) Integration With Climate and Land-Use Forecasts.  
   • Model scenarios of reduced or increased precipitation and changing irrigation practices to see how the aquifer might respond under different climate and management conditions.  
   • Update demand projections (e.g., changes in water rights or population) and couple them with the hydrologic conceptual model to quantify future groundwater availability and stream/aquifer flow patterns.
